citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The licensee stated that she is giving the dogs Tylosin Soluble Powder as an electrolyte source and 1/8th of a teaspoon
of the Tylosin is added to the water of dams with litters of puppies. The label on the Tylosin Powder says that it is an
antibiotic and it is to be used in turkeys, chickens, swine and honeybees. The use of the Tylosin Powder is not
documented as part of the Program of Veterinary Care and there is no other additional information indicating the
Attending Veterinarian has approved the off-label use of this product, how often it should be used, and the dosage that
should be given to dogs. The off-label use of a product must be approved by the attending veterinarian to ensure that it is
safe for the dogs to consume and it is being appropriately used.
Each dealer must use appropriate methods to prevent and control diseases and injuries. The licensee must have the use
of the Tylosin Powder approved by the Attending Veterinarian. The licensee must also ensure that the use of any product
off-label is approved by the Attending Veterinarian in order to protect the health and well-being of the dogs.
To be corrected by: 13-March-2023

At least three enclosures, housing a total of 3 adult dogs and 10 puppies, have plastic food and water bowls that have
been excessively chewed and damaged by the dogs. The damaged surfaces of the food and water bowls cannot be
readily cleaned and sanitized which could increase the risk of disease towards the dogs.
All surfaces must be maintained on a regular basis. Surfaces of housing facilities-including objects within the facility-that
cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized must be replaced when worn or soiled. The licensee must remove, replace, or
alter the damaged bowls in a manner that allows for cleaning and sanitization of the surfaces to occur. The licensee must
ensure all surfaces are properly maintained at all times in order to support the health and well-being of the animals.
To be corrected by: The licensee removed the damaged bowls at the time of the inspection.

The Program of Veterinary Care is incomplete and the schedule for the physical examinations by the attending
veterinarian of adult dogs and puppies is missing. The licensee stated that the attending veterinarian examines the dogs
on the following schedule:
* each adult dog is physically examined at least once every 12 months
* dams with litters are physically examined when the litter is 6 and/or 8 weeks of age
* puppies are examined when they are 6 and/or 8 weeks of age
Failure to document the schedule for physical examinations may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if
the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care.
Each dealer shall follow an appropriate program of veterinary care that is developed, documented in writing, signed by the
attending veterinarian and includes a complete physical examination from head to tail of each dog by the attending
veterinarian not less than once every 12 months. The licensee must add the schedule of physical examinations of adult
dogs and puppies to the Program of Veterinary Care to ensure that each animal is receiving adequate veterinary care.
To be corrected by: 13-March -2023

The licensee has not been testing the dogs for heartworm or intestinal parasites (fecals) and the Program of Veterinary
Care does not contain a written plan for heartworm and fecal testing. Testing for parasites is important in providing the
dogs with adequate veterinary care and identifying potential health issues before they worsen.
Each dealer must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care that is developed, documented in writing, and signed
by the attending veterinarian and contains the written plan to sample for parasites (including worms, giradia, coccidia,
heartworm). The licensee, in consultation with the Attending Veterinarian, must add the plan to sample for heartworm and
intestinal parasites to the Program of Veterinary Care in order to support the health and well-being of the animals.
To be corrected by: 13-March-2023

The Program of Veterinary Care is incomplete and the preventative care plans for maintaining healthy and unmatted hair
coats, properly trimmed toenails, and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth are missing. Failure to document these plans
may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care.
Each dealer must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care that is developed, documented in writing, signed by
the Attending Veterinarian and includes preventative care and treatment plans to maintain healthy and unmatted hair
coats, properly trimmed toenails, and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth. The licensee must add these preventative care
plans to the Program of Veterinary Care in order to ensure the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care.
To be corrected by: 13-March-2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
End Section

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The licensee stated that she is giving the dogs Tylosin Soluble Powder as an electrolyte source and 1/8th of a teaspoon 
of the Tylosin is added to the water of dams with litters of puppies. The label on the Tylosin Powder says that it is an 
antibiotic and it is to be used in turkeys, chickens, swine and honeybees.  The use of the Tylosin Powder is not 
documented as part of the Program of Veterinary Care and there is no other additional information indicating the 
Attending Veterinarian has approved the off-label use of this product, how often it should be used, and the dosage that 
should be given to dogs.  The off-label use of a product must be approved by the attending veterinarian to ensure that it is 
safe for the dogs to consume and it is being appropriately used.   
 
Each dealer must use appropriate methods to prevent and control diseases and injuries.  The licensee must have the use 
of the Tylosin Powder approved by the Attending Veterinarian.  The licensee must also ensure that the use of any product 
off-label is approved by the Attending Veterinarian in order to protect the health and well-being of the dogs. 
 
To be corrected by:  13-March-2023 
3.1(c)(2) 
   
Housing facilities, general.

At least three enclosures, housing a total of 3 adult dogs and 10 puppies, have plastic food and water bowls that have 
been excessively chewed and damaged by the dogs.  The damaged surfaces of the food and water bowls cannot be 
readily cleaned and sanitized which could increase the risk of disease towards the dogs.   
 
All surfaces must be maintained on a regular basis.  Surfaces of housing facilities-including objects within the facility-that 
cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized must be replaced when worn or soiled.  The licensee must remove, replace, or 
alter the damaged bowls in a manner that allows for cleaning and sanitization of the surfaces to occur.  The licensee must 
ensure all surfaces are properly maintained at all times in order to support the health and well-being of the animals. 
 
To be corrected by:  The licensee removed the damaged bowls at the time of the inspection. 
3.13(a)(2) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The Program of Veterinary Care is incomplete and the schedule for the physical examinations by the attending 
veterinarian of adult dogs and puppies is missing.  The licensee stated that the attending veterinarian examines the dogs 
on the following schedule: 
*  each adult dog is physically examined at least once every 12 months 
*  dams with litters are physically examined when the litter is 6 and/or 8 weeks of age 
*  puppies are examined when they are 6 and/or 8 weeks of age 
Failure to document the schedule for physical examinations may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if 
the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care.  
 
Each dealer shall follow an appropriate program of veterinary care that is developed, documented in writing, signed by the

attending veterinarian and includes a complete physical examination from head to tail of each dog by the attending 
veterinarian not less than once every 12 months.  The licensee must add the schedule of physical examinations of adult 
dogs and puppies to the Program of Veterinary Care to ensure that each animal is receiving adequate veterinary care. 
 
To be corrected by:  13-March -2023 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee has not been testing the dogs for heartworm or intestinal parasites (fecals) and the Program of Veterinary 
Care does not contain a written plan for heartworm and fecal testing.  Testing for parasites is important in providing the 
dogs with adequate veterinary care and identifying potential health issues before they worsen.   
 
Each dealer must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care that is developed, documented in writing, and signed 
by the attending veterinarian and contains the written plan to sample for parasites (including worms, giradia, coccidia, 
heartworm).  The licensee, in consultation with the Attending Veterinarian, must add the plan to sample for heartworm and 
intestinal parasites to the Program of Veterinary Care in order to support the health and well-being of the animals. 
 
To be corrected by:  13-March-2023 
3.13(a)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The Program of Veterinary Care is incomplete and the preventative care plans for maintaining healthy and unmatted hair 
coats, properly trimmed toenails, and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth are missing.  Failure to document these plans 
may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care.

Each dealer must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care that is developed, documented in writing, signed by 
the Attending Veterinarian and includes preventative care and treatment plans to maintain healthy and unmatted hair 
coats, properly trimmed toenails, and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth.  The licensee must add these preventative care 
plans to the Program of Veterinary Care in order to ensure the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care. 
 
To be corrected by:  13-March-2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative. 
 
End Section
